Items.A: The resistance of unknown resistor R is \[200\,\,\Omega \]
Items.subject: PHYSICS
Items.B: The equivalent resistance across AB is \[\frac{200}{3}\,\,\Omega \]
Items.C: The current in \[25\,\,\Omega \] resistor is \[\frac{2}{5}\] ampere
Items.D: The potential drop across \[120\,\,\Omega \] resistor is 60 volts
Items.solution: ampatiEquivalent resistance between P and Q \[=100\,\Omega \] So current towards \[P=\frac{400}{100}=4\,\,ampere\] Current through \[R=6-4=2\,\,ampere\] So, \[R=\frac{400}{2}=200\,\,\Omega \]
Items.q: The resistance of wire PQ is \[410\,\,\Omega \], which is tapped with the external wire as shown in the figure. The value of R is not known. When a battery of 400V is connected across AB, the net current through the source battery is 6 ampere. Then which of the following is/are correct.

Items.A: The energy stored in the space between 3R to 5R (cavity) is \[\frac{K{{q}^{2}}}{15R}\]
Items.subject: PHYSICS
Items.B: The energy stored in the space between 3R to 5R (cavity) is \[\frac{K{{q}^{2}}}{30R}\]
Items.C: The amount of work has to be performed to slowly transfer the charge ' q ' from centre through the orifice to infinity is \[\frac{29}{210}\,\,\frac{K{{q}^{2}}}{R}\]
Items.D: The amount of work has to be performed to slowly transfer the charge ' q ' from centre through the orifice to infinity is \[\frac{38}{105}\,\,\frac{K{{q}^{2}}}{R}\]
Items.solution:
AD
Work performed \[=\int\limits_{R}^{3R}{\frac{1}{2}{{\varepsilon }_{0}}{{E}^{2}}dV}+\int\limits_{5R}^{7R}{\frac{1}{2}{{\varepsilon }_{0}}{{E}^{2}}dV}=\frac{k{{q}^{2}}}{3R}+\frac{k{{q}^{2}}}{35R}\]

Items.C: Coordinates of ' P ' is \[\left( a+\Delta \,r,\,a+\Delta \,r,\,-\Delta \,r \right)\] and \[a > > \Delta \,r\], then flux passing through surface OABC is \[\frac{q}{24{{\varepsilon }_{0}}}\]
Items.D: Coordinates of ' P ' is \[\left( a+\Delta \,r,\,a+\Delta \,r,\,-\Delta \,r \right)\] and \[a > > \Delta \,r\], then flux passing through surface OCDE is \[\frac{q}{24{{\varepsilon }_{0}}}\]
Items.solution: ABCD Usinge symmetry if charged particle lies at \[{{P}_{1}}\] then \[{{\phi }_{OCDE}}=\frac{q}{24{{\varepsilon }_{0}}}\] and \[{{\phi }_{OABC}}=\frac{\left( \frac{q}{{{\varepsilon }_{0}}}-\frac{q}{8{{\varepsilon }_{0}}} \right)}{3}=\frac{7q}{24{{\varepsilon }_{0}}}\] If the charge particle lies at \[{{P}_{2}}\] then \[{{\phi }_{OCDE}}=\frac{q}{24{{\varepsilon }_{0}}}\] and \[{{\phi }_{OABC}}=\frac{q}{24{{\varepsilon }_{0}}}\]

Items.A: The greatest compression of the spring during the motion is 9 cm
Items.subject: PHYSICS
Items.B: The right body hits the wall again, when the spring is unstretched
Items.C: The change in the linear momentum of the system after all possible collisions will be 0.72 kgm/s
Items.D: Finally both the bodies will have same velocity
Items.solution: Immediately after 1 st collision : Since the situation is symmetric, both will come to rest simultaneously. \[{{x}_{0}}\] : maximum compression \[\therefore \,\,\,2\times \frac{1}{2}\,mv_{0}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\,kx_{0}^{2}\] \[\therefore \,\,\,{{x}_{0}}={{v}_{0}}\sqrt{\frac{2m}{K}}\] Just before 2 nd collision : Finally : \[\therefore \,\,\,\Delta \,\overrightarrow{P}=4\,m{{v}_{0}}\,\,\left( \leftarrow \right)\]
Items.q: Bodies of mass m = 0.5 kg, resting on a horizontal frictionless table, are connected with an unstretched spring of length L = 20 cm, and of spring constant k=16N/m. The mass of the spring is negligible. At a certain moment the bodies are given an initial speed of \[{{v}_{0}}=0.36\,\,m/s\], towards the wall on the right. The collision with the wall is perfectly elastic.

Items.A: The tension in the thread when the angle between the thread and the horizontal is \[\phi \] is \[T=\left( 3\sin \phi \sin \alpha -2\mu \phi \cos \alpha \right)\,mg\]
Items.subject: PHYSICS
Items.B: The tension in the string will be maximum when \[\phi =90{}^\circ \]
Items.C: The tension in the string will be maximum when \[\phi ={{\cos }^{-1}}\left( \frac{2\mu }{3\tan \alpha } \right)\]
Items.D: The maximum speed of the particle will be when \[\phi ={{\cos }^{-1}}\,\left( \mu \cot \alpha \right)\]
Items.solution: ACD \[T-mg\sin \alpha \sin \phi =\frac{m{{v}^{2}}}{\ell }\] (i) \[mg\sin \alpha \cos \phi -\mu \,mg\cos \alpha =m\frac{dv}{dt}\] (ii) work energy theorem \[\left( mg\sin \alpha \right)\,\ell \sin \alpha -\left( \mu mg\cos \alpha \right)\,\ell \,\phi =\frac{1}{2}\,m{{v}^{2}}\] (iii) From (i) and (iii) \[\Rightarrow \,\,\,\,T-mg\sin \alpha \sin \phi =\alpha \,mg\sin \alpha \,\sin \phi -2\left( \mu \,mg\,\cos \alpha \right)\,\phi \] \[\Rightarrow \,\,\,\,T=mg\left( 3\,\sin \alpha \,\sin \phi -2\,\mu \,\phi \,\cos \,\alpha \right)\] \[\frac{dT}{d\phi }=0=3\,\sin \,\alpha \,\,\cos \phi -2\mu \,\cos \alpha \]
Items.q: One end of a thread of length \[\ell =1\,m\] is attached to an inclined plane of angle of elevation of \[\alpha =30{}^\circ \]. A point-like body of mass m = 1 kg is attached to the other end of the thread as shown in the figure. The body is released without initial speed, such that the thread is tight and horizontal. The coefficient of friction between the slope and the body is \[\mu =0.2\].

Items.subTopic: nth root of a complex number
Items.solution: 144 equation of parabola \[y=k{{x}^{2}}\] \[y=h=k{{a}^{2}}\] \[k=\left( \frac{h}{{{a}^{2}}} \right)\] \[y=\left( \frac{h}{{{a}^{2}}} \right)\,{{x}^{2}}\] \[R=\frac{{{\left[ 1+{{\left( \frac{dy}{dx} \right)}^{2}} \right]}^{3/2}}}{\frac{{{d}^{2}}y}{d{{x}^{2}}}}\] \[R\left( x=0 \right)=\left( \frac{1}{2k} \right)\] \[mg-N=\frac{m{{v}^{2}}}{R}\]

A car of mass 72 kg is crossing the bridge at a constant speed of 5 m/s. Find the force (in Newton) exerted on the bridge by car when it is at the highest point ' P ' of the bridge. (take \[g=10\,\,m/{{s}^{2}}\])

Items.subject: PHYSICS
Items.solution: 1.35 \[{{Q}_{ice}}=KA\left( \frac{400-0}{13.5-x} \right)\,t\] So ice melt, \[{{m}_{ice}}=\frac{{{Q}_{ice}}}{{{L}_{F}}}=\frac{KA\left( 400-0 \right)\,t}{80\,\left( 13.5-x \right)}\] (i) \[{{Q}_{water}}=KA\frac{\left( 400-100 \right)}{x}\,t\] \[{{m}_{steam}}=\frac{{{Q}_{water}}}{{{L}_{V}}}=\frac{KA\left( 400-100 \right)}{540\,x}\,t\] (ii) \[{{m}_{ice}}={{m}_{steam}}\] \[\frac{400}{80\left( 13.5-x \right)}=\frac{300}{540\,x}\] \[6\left( 13.5-x \right)=54\,x\] \[6\times 13.5=\left( 54x-6x \right)\] \[x=\frac{6\times 13.5}{60}=1.35\,m\]

Items.C: The axial P – Cl bonds are weaker than the equatorial P – Cl bonds.

Items.solution:
Geometry of \[\text{P}{{\text{F}}_{\text{5}}}\] is trigonal bipyramidal with \[\text{s}{{\text{p}}^{\text{3}}}\]d hybridization, in which there are two sets of hybrid orbitals \[\text{s}{{\text{p}}^{\text{2}}}\] in equatorial plane and \[{{\text{p}}_{\text{z}}}{{\text{d}}_{\text{z}}}^{\text{2}}\] in axial direction. Axial bonds are longer and weaker than equatorial P
–
F bonds.

Items.solution:
\[\left. \begin{align}
&
{{f}^{1}}\left( x+y \right)={{f}^{1}}\left( x \right)+{{e}^{x}}\left( {{e}^{y}}-1 \right) \\
&
{{f}^{1}}\left( x+y \right)={{f}^{1}}\left( y \right)+{{e}^{y}}\left( {{e}^{x}}-1 \right) \\
\end{align} \right\}\,\,\Rightarrow \,\,\,\,{{f}^{1}}\left( x \right)-{{e}^{x}}=k\,\,\,\Rightarrow \,\,\,\,\,{{f}^{1}}\left( x \right)=k+{{e}^{x}}\]
But \[\text{f}\left( 0 \right)=0,\text{ }{{\text{f}}^{\text{1}}}\left( 0 \right)=\text{2}\]
\[\therefore \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\]
\[{{\text{f}}^{\text{1}}}\left( \text{x} \right)~={{\text{e}}^{\text{x}}}+\text{1}
>
0\] \[\Rightarrow \]
f is increasing
\[\begin{align}
&
f\left( -\infty
\right)=-\infty
\\
&
f\left( \infty
\right)=\infty
\\
\end{align}\]
\[\therefore \]No of solutions of \[\text{f}\left( \text{x} \right)=0\] is 1
Also \[\underset{x\to 0}{\mathop{Lt}}\,{{\left( f\left( x \right)+\cos x \right)}^{\frac{1}{{{e}^{x}}-1}}}\,\,\,\,\,\left( {{1}^{\infty }} \right)={{e}^{\underset{x\to o}{\mathop{Lt}}\,}}\left( \frac{f\left( x+\cos x-1 \right)}{{{e}^{x-1}}} \right)\]
= \[{{e}^{\underset{x\to o}{\mathop{Lt}}\,}}\frac{{{e}^{x}}++\cos x-2}{{{e}^{x}}-1}={{e}^{2}}\]
Also \[\left. \begin{align}
&
f\left( 0 \right)
>
0 \\
&
f\left( -1 \right)
<
0 \\
\end{align} \right\}\,\,\alpha \,\,\,\,\in \left( -1,0 \right)\,\,\Rightarrow \,\,G.E={{\tan }^{-1}}\alpha +\left( -\pi +{{\cot }^{-1}}\alpha
\right)=-\frac{\pi }{2}\]
Also \[\underset{x\to 0}{\mathop{Lt}}\,\,\frac{-{{e}^{x}}+x-1}{x}=2\]

Equation of \[{{\text{C}}_{\text{2}}}\].
\[(x-3){{\,}^{2}}\,+{{(y+1)}^{2}}\,=9\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,{{x}^{2}}+{{y}^{2}}\,-6x+2y\,+1=0\] For
\[{{C}_{1}}\,\sin \,45{}^\circ \,\,=\sqrt{\frac{{{(3-2)}^{2}}+{{(2-1)}^{2}}}{r}\,}\,\,\,\,r=\sqrt{2}\sqrt{2}=2\].
Centre (4,1)

Solving \[{{C}_{1}}and\,\,{{C}_{2}}\,\,\,2x+4y-12=0\,\,\,\,\,x=6-2y\]
Put value of x in (1) and after solving
\[y=1-\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}\,},\,\,\,x=4+\frac{4}{\sqrt{5}}\]

Equation of the joining (2+i) and (4+3i) is

Intersection of \[\text{x}-\text{y }-\text{1}=\text{9}\]with \[{{C}_{2}}\,\,{{(x-3)}^{2}}\,+{{(x-1+1)}^{2}}=9\,\,\,\Rightarrow \,\,x=0,3\,\,\,\,\,x=0\Rightarrow y=-1\]

will be zero.

Items.q: P is a set consisting of those points which lie on the portion of a curve given by \[\arg \,\left( \frac{3z-6-3i}{2z-8-6i} \right)=\frac{\pi }{4}\,.\]Q is a set consisting of those points which lie on the curve given by \[\left| z-3+i \right|=3\], then which of following statement(s) is /are true

Items.A: If A and B are square matrices of the same order such that ABAB = 0, it follows that BABA = 0.
Items.subject: MATHEMATICS
Items.B: Let A and B be different n × n matrices with real numbers. If \[{{\text{A}}^{\text{3}}}={{\text{B}}^{\text{3}}}\] and \[{{\text{A}}^{\text{2}}}\text{B}={{\text{B}}^{\text{2}}}\text{A}\], then \[{{\text{A}}^{\text{2}}}+{{\text{B}}^{\text{2}}}\] is invertible.
Items.C: If A is a square, non-singular and symmetric matrix, then \[{{\left( {{\left( {{A}^{-1}} \right)}^{-1}} \right)}^{-1}}\] is skew symmetric.
Items.D: The matrix of the product of two invertible square matrices of the same order is also invertible.
Items.solution:
(A) \[A=\left[ \begin{matrix}
0
&
0
&
1
\\
0
&
0
&
0
\\
0
&
1
&
0
\\
\end{matrix} \right]\];
\[B=\left[ \begin{matrix}
0
&
0
&
1
\\
1
&
0
&
0
\\
0
&
0
&
0
\\
\end{matrix} \right]\]
is a counter example. Therefore, (A) is wrong.
(B) We have \[\left( {{\text{A}}^{\text{2}}}+{{\text{B}}^{\text{2}}} \right)\left( \text{A}\text{B} \right)={{\text{A}}^{\text{3}}}{{\text{B}}^{\text{3}}}{{\text{A}}^{\text{2}}}\text{B}+{{\text{B}}^{\text{2}}}\text{A}=0\]
and \[A-B\ne 0\]
⇒
\[{{\text{A}}^{\text{2}}}\text{+}{{\text{B}}^{\text{2}}}\] is not invertible. Therefore (B) is also wrong.
(C) \[{{\text{A}}^{\text{T}}}=\text{A}\]
\[{{\left( {{\left( {{A}^{-1}} \right)}^{-1}} \right)}^{-1}}={{A}^{-1}}\]
\[{{\left( {{A}^{-1}} \right)}^{T}}={{\left( {{A}^{T}} \right)}^{-1}}={{A}^{-1}}\]
So,
\[{{\left( {{\left( {{A}^{-1}} \right)}^{-1}} \right)}^{-1}}\] is also symmetric. Therefore (C) is also wrong.
(D) \[|A|\ne 0,\,\,|B|\ne 0\,\,\Rightarrow \,\,|AB|\ne 0\]

Items.solution: Clearly domain and Range of g(x) are [- 1, 1) and { π } respectively \[{{\cos }^{-1}}\left( \cos x \right)=-x\] for x \[\in \] [- 1, 0] ∴ For \[-1\le x\le 0\] the equation becomes \[-\text{ x}+\pi =\text{3}\] \[x=\pi -3\,\notin \left[ -1,\,0 \right]\] \[\therefore \] No solution. \[\text{co}{{\text{s}}^{-\text{1}}}\left( \text{cos x} \right)=\text{x}\] for \[x\in [0,\,1)\] For \[0\le x\le 1\] equation becomes \[\text{x}+\pi =\text{3}\] x = 3-\[\pi \]\[\notin \left[ 0,\,\,1 \right]\] \[\therefore \] no solution.

Items.solution: \[f\left( x \right)=\int\limits_{0}^{x}{{{e}^{x-t}}dt+\int\limits_{x}^{1}{{{e}^{t-x}}.dt}}\] \[=\left( -{{e}^{x-t}} \right)_{0}^{x}+\left( {{e}^{t-x}} \right)_{x}^{1}=\left( -1 \right)-\left( -{{e}^{x}} \right)+{{e}^{1-x}}-1={{e}^{x}}+{{e}^{1-x}}-2\] \[\therefore f\left( x \right)={{e}^{x}}+{{e}^{1-x}}-2\] \[{{f}^{|}}\left( x \right)={{e}^{x}}+{{e}^{1-x}}=0\Rightarrow \,\,\,\,x=\frac{1}{2}\] f decreases in \[\left( 0,\frac{1}{2} \right)\] f increases in \[f\left( x \right)=\frac{\left[ f\left( 1+\frac{h}{x} \right)-f\left( 1 \right) \right]}{h}-2.\frac{f\left( 1+\frac{h}{x} \right)-f\left( 1 \right)}{h}\] \[\therefore \] f has min at \[x=\frac{1}{2}\] \[{{f}_{\min }}=f\left( \frac{1}{2} \right)={{e}^{\frac{1}{2}}}+{{e}^{\frac{1}{2}}}-2=2\left( \sqrt{e}-1 \right)\] Also \[f\left( 0 \right)=1+e-2=e-1\] \[f\left( 1 \right)=e+1-2=e-1\] Maximum of \[f\left( x \right)={{f}_{\max }}=e-1\]
